014package org.jdbi.v3.core.statement;
015
016import java.sql.SQLException;
017import java.sql.Statement;
018
019import org.jdbi.v3.core.Handle;
020import org.jdbi.v3.core.result.ResultBearing;
021import org.jdbi.v3.core.result.ResultProducer;
022import org.jdbi.v3.core.result.ResultProducers;
023import org.jdbi.v3.core.result.ResultSetScanner;
024import org.jdbi.v3.core.result.UnableToProduceResultException;
025
026/**
027 * Statement providing convenience result handling for SQL queries.
028 */
029public class Query extends SqlStatement<Query> implements ResultBearing {
030    public Query(Handle handle, CharSequence sql) {
031        super(handle, sql);
032    }
033
034    /**
035     * Deprecated delegate - please use {@code CharSequence} signature for future compatibility.
036     */
037    public Query(Handle handle, String sql) {
038        super(handle, (CharSequence) sql);
039    }
040
041    /**
042     * Executes the query, returning the result obtained from the given {@link ResultProducer}.
043     *
044     * @param <R> the type of the result
045     * @param producer the result producer.
046     * @return value returned by the result producer.
047     */
048    public <R> R execute(ResultProducer<R> producer) {
049        try {
050            return producer.produce(this::internalExecute, getContext());
051        } catch (SQLException e) {
052            try {
053                close();
054            } catch (Exception e1) {
055                e.addSuppressed(e1);
056            }
057            throw new UnableToProduceResultException(e, getContext());
058        }
059    }
060
061    @Override
062    public <R> R scanResultSet(ResultSetScanner<R> mapper) {
063        return execute(ResultProducers.returningResults()).scanResultSet(mapper);
064    }
065
066    /**
067     * Specify the fetch size for the query. This should cause the results to be
068     * fetched from the underlying RDBMS in groups of rows equal to the number passed.
069     * This is useful for doing chunked streaming of results when exhausting memory
070     * could be a problem.
071     *
072     * @param fetchSize the number of rows to fetch in a bunch
073     *
074     * @return the modified query
075     */
076    public Query setFetchSize(final int fetchSize) {
077        return addCustomizer(StatementCustomizers.fetchSize(fetchSize));
078    }
079
080    /**
081     * Specify the maximum number of rows the query is to return. This uses the underlying JDBC
082     * {@link Statement#setMaxRows(int)}}.
083     *
084     * @param maxRows maximum number of rows to return
085     *
086     * @return modified query
087     */
088    public Query setMaxRows(final int maxRows) {
089        return addCustomizer(StatementCustomizers.maxRows(maxRows));
090    }
091
092    /**
093     * Specify the maximum field size in the result set. This uses the underlying JDBC
094     * {@link Statement#setMaxFieldSize(int)}
095     *
096     * @param maxFields maximum field size
097     *
098     * @return modified query
099     */
100    public Query setMaxFieldSize(final int maxFields) {
101        return addCustomizer(StatementCustomizers.maxFieldSize(maxFields));
102    }
103
104    /**
105     * Specify that the result set should be concurrent updatable.
106     *
107     * This will allow the update methods to be called on the result set produced by this
108     * Query.
109     *
110     * @return the modified query
111     */
112    public Query concurrentUpdatable() {
113        getContext().setConcurrentUpdatable(true);
114        return this;
115    }
116}
